results.title: Catch of the day
results.creator_credit: Sarah Watt, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The bright, beautiful and spontaneous ocean is something to wallow in. A young girl plays in the ocean and with the fishes. A dashing surfer rides up on his white steed and declares ‘I’ve come - you’ll never have to chop onions again!’ Jane wakes up from her dream (or was it a nightmare?) Working at the fish market, she endures the sexual innuendo and double entendres from male customers and fellow workers alike. When matters come to a head, she cleverly takes the situation into her own hands and offers a unique solution to unsolicited sexual advances… An impressionistic animation.

results.title: Bare
results.creator_credit: Deborah Strutt, Liz Baulch, Wild Iris Productions and Amanda Roberts
results.brief_description: There are misunderstandings aplenty in this award-winning Australian short when 2 gay boys accidentally catch their lesbian neighbours in an early morning clinch. High density living in all its revealing glory.

results.title: Pierre et Paul = Pierre and Paul
results.creator_credit: Rene Allio, Leon Carre and Yves Robert
results.brief_description:
Pierre, a middle manager in a building company, decides to buy a appartment and live with his girlfriend, Martine. But, the subsequent death of his father and various financial difficulties soon damage his mental equilibrium. When the May ‘68 riots errupt, Pierre goes off the rails.

Credits: Producer, Leon Carre, Yves Robert ; director, Rene Allio ; writer, Rene Allio ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Jacques Dutronc.
Cast: Pierre Mondy, Robert Juillard, Bulle Ogier, Madeleine Barbulee, Helene Vincent.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV

results.title: "War Pictures": Australians at the Cinema 1914-1918
results.brief_description:
A compilation of archival films that chronicles the Australian cinema-going experience during WWI from 1914 to 1918.

Between 1914 and 1918, cinema attendance was on the rise and the local film industry was expanding with over 50 Australian feature films produced during the period. While many of these films have been tragically lost, those that remain offer a rare glimpse into Australian life during this turbulent time.

As the war began, filmmakers rushed to make features about Australia’s involvement. Alfred Rolfe’s ‘Hero of the Dardanelles’ (1915) told the story of Gallipoli, complete with landing scenes shot at Tamarama Beach in Sydney.

However, as the years progressed, war-weary audiences lost their taste for patriotic stories, and a new genre of home-grown comedies emerged featuring knockabout characters from the Australian bush. Throughout the war years, Hollywood dramas, serials, love stories and comedies were also staple attractions, and Charlie Chaplin was an international superstar.

War Pictures offers a wide-ranging selection of local and international material, including a focus on Australia’s ‘lost films’.

Specially commissioned introductions and musical accompaniment offer contemporary audiences a chance to step back time and experience cinema as it was enjoyed during the First World War.

This work was shown at ACMI from 10 March to 26 July 2015 in the ‘War Pictures’ exhibition.

results.title: Three in one
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes and Australian Tradition Films
results.brief_description: A trilogy of Australian stories about mateship. “Joe Wilson’s Mates”, from a story by Henry Lawson, is set in the 1890’s and is about a stranger in town who dies alone, but is given a funeral because he carries a Union Card. “The Load of Wood”, from a story by Frank Hardy, is set during the depression of the 1930’s. “The City”, is a love story set in Sydney in the 1950’s. The three stories are linked by introductory comments from John McCallum, who also narrates them. Cast includes Leonard Teale, Edmund Allison, Jock Levy, Joan Landor, Brian Vicery, Reg Lye.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film is a series of shorter films from different periods edited together. They include trips to Lake Eildon and the Eildon Weir Spillway and Dromana Beach. Streets of Ballarat and Alexandra are also briefly seen.

We see a doubles tennis tournament at Kooyong Stadium and a scene of the 1936 Australian golf exhibition tour with Gene Sarazen (USA), Jim Ferrier (Australia) and Helen Hicks (USA), the first professional female golfer in the world.

Included are members of the Parsons family, also playing tennis and golf, and towards the end of the film there is a raquet technique demonstration from Robin (George Robinson) Parsons himself.

In addition to showing fashions of the time there are brief scenes showing vehicles of the era, including a steam locomotive, ships, a row boat and horses. The two main vehicles seen are the family cars: a 1935 Chevrolet and 1933 Rover.

The film also includes a few scenes of dogs playing and doing tricks including the family terrier called Peter.

results.title: The Magic Trumpet
results.creator_credit: Dusan Marek, Anim-ad Films and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: An experimental film using mainly animated paper cut-outs to tell the story of a magic trumpet which brings fame and fortune to an old tramp. Story script by Tim Burstall, music by Michael Kenny and montage, animation and photography by Dusan Marek.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

Selected Highlights List
00:00:02:00 – Geoffrey and Jean Parsons playing with a Fox Terrier
00:01:12:00 – Wedding of Mary Dowling Woods and John Bedggood
00:02:07:00 – Melbourne Grammar Sports day at the MCG
00:03:52:00 – The Rose family, Aeneas Gunn and Robin Parsons at the Rose family home with dogs
00:05:10:00 – Doug Rose and Aeneas Gunn riding a cow
00:07:34:00 – Steam boat on the Yarra River
00:07:48:00 – Parson family and friends swimming at Dromana beach showing 1930’s swimming costumes
00:08:44:00 Sidney and Susannah Parsons at Dromana Beach
00:09:53:00 – Parsons family doing Acrobats, playing games and making a human tower at Dromana Beach
00:10:55:00 – Bi Planes – VH–UHR, VH-UHS and VH-UAT
00:12:23:00 – Two women and Geoffrey Parsons on a rug in the garden of the family home
00:14:01:00 – Susannah Parsons demonstrating her golfing swing
00:14:52:00 – View of Princes bridge with Flinders Street Railway station in the Background
00:15:20:00 – View towards the Flinders street Fish Market (demolished in 1956)
00:15:26:00 – Steam boats docked on the Yarra river.
00:15:46:00 – Navy ship in the harbour
00:16:06:00 – The shrine of Remembrance (before the gardens were there) and views of Melbourne from its balcony.
00:21:28:00 – View of Collins Street from the roof of the Parson Bros Mill near Spencer street station, showing the 1935 centennial celebrations parade
00:22:45:00 – Sidney Parsons, Robin Parsons and unknown man playing golf
00:23:56:00 - View from the rooftop of Parsons Bros Mill on Collins Street looking up towards the Victorian Railway administration offices on Spencer street and down Flinders Lane.
00:24:20:00 – People lining Nicholson street (near parliament gardens) to watch lavish floats and masked performers.
00:30:56:00 – Parson family members at the beach in Dromana
00:37:24:00 – Doug and Charlie Parsons climbing the sign labelled the highest house in Australia at Hotham Heights and camping trip
00:42:30:00 – Front view of motorbike with side car following on the road in wet weather
00:27:23:00 – Parson brothers, friends and fiancée Jean, on the coast of Cape Shanck.
00:42:59:00 – Jean Parsons (portrait view)
00:43:03:00 – Robin Parsons (portrait view) smoking
00:43:18:00 – 1939 Australian Championship, Kooyong Stadium – John Bromwich and Adrian Quist
00:43:56:00 – Wedding of unknown couple
00:44:42:00 – VH-USQ Cierva C.30A Auto gyro (Gyrocopter)
00:46:37:00 – The Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane off Dromana Beach. Geoffrey Parsons climbing out of the Cockpit. (VH-UNV)
00:47:51:00 – Douglas DC-2 Airliner VH-USY “Bungana” outside Holymans hangar at Melbourne/Essendon airport
00:48:24:00 – Miles M-3 Merlin (VH-UXN) (Came to Australia in 1936)
00:48:41:00 – De Havilland D.H. 86A express (VH-UUB) Loila outside Holymans Hanger at Melbourne Essendon airport
00:53:23:00 – Rifle shooting in the snow at Mount Hotham

description_for_label:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.
